biogHists.text:
The 20th Commemoration of the Kent State shootings, held in 1990, remains one of the largest-attended of all the annual gatherings. Preparations had begun a few years in advance, culminating in the creation of the May 4 20th Anniversary Commission, at the behest of President Michael Schwartz, in 1989. The Commission's recommendations included the establishment of a platform party and a list of speakers and events. In addition, the May 4 Memorial, designed by Bruno Ast, was formally dedicated at the commemoration on May 4, 1990.

From the description of May 4 20th Commemoration records, 1985-1991 (bulk 1990-1991). (Kent State University). WorldCat record id: 457049209

The Kent State University photo directories were previously known as the Photo Directory and Profiles "Look Around" before being known as the New Student Record. These publications were produced from 1967 through 1992 and were under the authority of the Student Government, Office of Advising and Orientation/Inter-Fraternity Council, Kent State Greeks, and most commonly the Orientation Honor Society. These photo directories, similar to yearbooks, were intended for use by incoming freshmen as a means to become acquainted with their fellow peers, university traditions and customs and other general information about Kent State University.

From the guide to the Kent State University New Student Record collection, 1967-1992, (Kent State University Libraries. Special Collections and Archives.)

From the formation of a mustache club in 1926, to the controversial events of May 4, 1970, the Daily Kent Stater has played an integral role in documenting the history of Kent State University. The student-run daily campus newspaper first appeared as the Searchlight on February 25, 1926. Just over five months after its establishment, the Searchlight was replaced by the Kent Stater on July 29, 1926. The newspaper took on its current title as the Daily Kent Stater in December of 1953. Today, the Daily Kent Stater is published Monday through Friday during the regular school year, and weekly on Wednesdays during the summer months. The newspaper also maintains an online edition currently called KentWired.com, published jointly with Kent State University's TV-2.

From the guide to the Daily Kent Stater microfilm collection, 1926-2013, (Kent State University Libraries. Special Collections and Archives.)

The 20th Commemoration of the shootings on May 4, 1970 remains one of the largest attended of all the annual gatherings. Preparations began a few years in advance, culminating in the official creation of the May 4 20th Anniversary Commission, at the behest of President Michael Schwartz, in 1989. Among other obligations, the Commission issued a report with recommendations for the Commemoration. These recommendations included the establishment of a platform party and a list of possible speakers and events for May 4, 1990. In addition, the May 4 Memorial, designed by Bruno Ast, was formally dedicated at the 20th Commemoration on May 4, 1990.

From the guide to the May 4 20th Commemoration records, 1985-1991, 1990-1991, (Kent State University Libraries. Special Collections and Archives.)

The Kent State University student handbooks, commonly referred to as "K" books, were produced each academic year from approximately 1928-1970 (exceptions noted) under the authority of Student Council, and later both Student Council and the Publications Policy Committee. These generally pocket-sized guides were intended for use by incoming freshmen as a means of becoming acquainted with university rules, regulations, traditions and customs, activities, campus organizations and other information about life at Kent State University. There are several academic years during which the books were either not published, or if they were published, they are not currently included in this collection. More detail on available dates can be found in the scope and content.

From the guide to the Kent State University student handbook ("K" book) collection, 1928-1970, (Kent State University Libraries. Special Collections and Archives.)

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Varsity "K" Club is a social organization of former Kent State University varsity-letter winners in every athletic event. This collection includes administrative records, correspondence, photographs, news clippings, and artifacts. This collection documents the Varsity "K" Club from its inception as the "K" Men's Club of Kent State Normal College up through its establishment as the co-ed Varsity "K" Club of Kent State University. The collection includes administrative records, correspondence, newsclippings, publications, and photographs of the Varsity "K" Club, the Kent State University Varsity "K" Hall of Fame, and prominent KSU athletes and sporting events. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Dennis Hearn papers, 1871-1998 (bulk 1940-1998).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The personal and professional papers of actor and Kent State University alumnus Dennis Hearn. The Dennis Hearn papers consist of material relating to Hearn's family, his youth in Chesterland, Ohio, and his life as a working actor and businessman. Materials include family photograph albums, scrapbooks and loose photographs (late 1930s-1990s); family and church-related newspaper clippings documenting life in Chesterland, Ohio (1950s-1970s); programs, photographs and other material related to Hearn's theatrical career (1960s-1990s) and subject files regarding Hearn's business ventures, friends, and colleagues. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1977-1978.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection documents the 1977-1978 protests against construction of the gymnasium annex at Kent State University. The central issue was the annex site, near the place where four students were killed on May 4, 1970. Friction between protesters and the University administration resulted in rallies with as many as 2,000 participants. The materials in this collection document the protests with typescripts, photographs, newspaper articles, protest literature, and UPI dispatches. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Also included is material from Jerris' successor, J. Stanley Pottinger, when the investigation was reopened three years later. </abstract>

                     <role>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>May 4 Task Force records, 1986-2009 (bulk 2005-2009).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Materials that document the proceedings of the May 4 Task Force, a student organization at Kent State University. Included are minutes, financial records, news clippings, and materials pertaining to the annual commemoration of the Kent State shootings. To date, this collection ranges from approximately 1986 to 2009 and is organized alphabetically by series and chronologically within each series and subseries. Series 2 ( Event Materials) and Series 4 (Organizational Materials) are dated by school year, following the fall to spring semester schedule. There are significant gaps between years with the bulk of documents dating from 2005 to 2009. The collection is comprised of correspondence, event materials, news clippings and publications, and organizational materials. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

                     <title>Akron Beacon Journal Kent State Shootings collection, 1969-1983 (bulk 1970).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection contains photocopies of documents pertaining to the Ohio State Highway Patrol and the Federal Bureau of Investigation reports on the Kent State shootings. These materials were obtained by the staff of the Akron Beacon Journal through Freedom of Information Act requests from the U.S. Department of Justice. Included are inter-office correspondence, autopsy reports of the victims, and notes pertaining to the investigation. The Federal Bureau of Investigation records include various reports from agents assigned to investigating the shootings and comprise an earlier draft of the FBI's final report. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>

                  <name>
                     <namePart>American Civil Liberties Union of Ohio.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>ACLU of Ohio Kent State Project records, 1960-1980 (inclusive), 1970-1978 (bulk).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Records of ACLU of Ohio attorneys document preparation for the retrial of Krause v. Rhodes in 1978. Because the retrial was the culmination of a long, difficult legal battle for accountability in the deaths of four students and the injury of nine others, the collection includes not just materials assembled specifically for the 1978 trial, but also materials gathered for previous lawsuits related to the May 4th, 1970, shootings at Kent State University. The collection includes documents filed in various courts such as briefs, memoranda and motions, transcripts of trial proceedings, and depositions. It also includes materials produced by the attorneys and their staff, such as correspondence, research memoranda, legal stragety communications, and witness files of individuals who testified at one or more trials. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>

                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:664362672</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-KSU</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Johnson, J. T. (John Thomas), 1869-1956.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>J.T. Johnson papers, 1865-1950 (bulk 1880-1930).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The J.T. Johnson papers, dating from the mid-19th to the mid-20th century, document both the personal and academic life of John Thomas Johnson, the first Dean of Kent State Normal School, as well as Head of the Agriculture Department. Johnson was a skilled amateur photographer, and photographs form the bulk of this collection. The collection includes family photographs, early Kent State Normal School campus scenes and buildings (1912 to circa 1930), and photographic studies of plant, insect and bird life. The collection also includes newspaper clippings, programs and other ephemera, much of it related to the early history of Kent State University, including commencement programs, programs for entertainments held on campus, and University School (the working campus teacher training school) publications. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: J.T. Johnson papers, 1865-1950 (bulk 1880-1930).
resource.abstract: The J.T. Johnson papers, dating from the mid-19th to the mid-20th century, document both the personal and academic life of John Thomas Johnson, the first Dean of Kent State Normal School, as well as Head of the Agriculture Department. Johnson was a skilled amateur photographer, and photographs form the bulk of this collection. The collection includes family photographs, early Kent State Normal School campus scenes and buildings (1912 to circa 1930), and photographic studies of plant, insect and bird life. The collection also includes newspaper clippings, programs and other ephemera, much of it related to the early history of Kent State University, including commencement programs, programs for entertainments held on campus, and University School (the working campus teacher training school) publications.

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Robert C. Dix May 4 papers, 1944-1996 (bulk 1969-1972).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection contains the personal papers of Robert C. Dix, member of the Kent State University Board of Trustees from 1941-1973. The materials focus on the events surrounding the May 4, 1970, shootings on campus and provide a glimpse into the University's response to the events from an administrative perspective. The materials include personal correspondence (much of it involving Robert White, president of Kent State University from 1963-1971), University documents, and internal communications. The collection spans the years 1944 to 1996, but the bulk of the materials are from the time of the 1970 Kent State Shootings and the student unrest on campus in 1969. The collection also contains documents pertaining to the many legal proceedings following the Kent State Shootings including the Special Grand Jury called in September of 1970, the President's Commission on Campus Unrest, and the Ohio General Assembly's legislative response to the events. Also present is a collection of news clippings from 1970. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:40843559</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-KSU</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Students for a Democratic Society (U.S.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Records, 1965-1974.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection contains various types of documentation and records which chronicle events precipitating and subsequent to the May 4, 1970, shootings on the Kent State University campus as well as other materials from the period.  The primary focus of the collection is the activity of the S.D.S. (Students for a Democratic Society), a militant anti-war group.  Included is a brief history of the development of the S.D.S. by Gary Allen, who was president of the Foundation for Economic and Social Progress at the time.  Propaganda pamphlets and position statements from S.D.S. and other militant groups, as well as radio and television transcripts are among the items collected.  Other materials present include S.D.S. rally posters, adhesive-backed stickers, and three photographs, one of which was taken the morning of May 4th. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <title>Kent State University Regional Campuses Office records, 1950-2009 (bulk 1980-2000).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Kent State University Regional Campuses Office is the central office for Kent State University's seven regional campuses. This collection contains materials from 1950-2009 related to various activities of the Regional Campuses Office, and includes paper records, photographs, slides, negatives, microfiche, microfilm, and audio-visual materials. The Kent State University, Regional Campuses Office records include administrative and other materials of the Regional Campuses Office. This collection consists mainly of materials from 1950-2009, the majority of which are from 1980-2000. The original order of materials originally in file folders has been maintained. Files belonging to Series 1-3 contain correspondence, curriculum and program proposals, reports and surveys, meeting minutes, and other administrative documentation. Series 4 contains documents, correspondence, negatives, slides, and photographs relating to various events held by the Regional Campuses office. Series 5 contains mostly microfiche of enrollment statistics and other subject files. Series 6 consists of promotional audio-visual materials, as well as an award plaque. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.title: J. B. Matthews Papers, 1862-1986 and undated
resource.abstract: J. B. Matthews (1894-1966) was a Methodist missionary, college professor, author, lecturer, and prominent conservative spokesman. Collection consists of correspondence, memoranda, statements, speeches, reprints, clippings, broadsides, newsletters, press releases, petitions, and other printed material, chiefly 1930-1969. The principal focus of the collection relates to the work and research of Matthews and his associates in the area of anti-communism, particularly in connection with Matthews' role as Director of Research for the Special Committee on Un-American Activities of the U.S. House of Representatives (1938-1945), Executive Director of the Permanent Subcommittee on Government Operations of the U.S. Senate (1953), and a consultant for John A. Clements Associates. Many of the organizations, newspapers, periodicals, and persons represented in the collection have various leftist, socialist, communist, radical, or pacifist (especially anti-Vietnam War) connections.Individuals represented in the files include Ralph Abernathy, Bella Abzug, Roy Cohn, John Foster Dulles, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Michael Harrington, Alger Hiss, J. Edgar Hoover, Jesse Jackson, John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King, Coretta Scott King, Joseph Lash, Joseph McCarthy, Carl McIntire, Benjamin Mandel, Richard Nixon, Aristotle Onassis, Lee Harvey Oswald, Linus Pauling, Drew Pearson, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Louis Untermeyer.
resource.displayEntry: J. B. Matthews Papers, 1862-1986 and undated

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:34163220</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-KSU</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Nurmi, Martin K.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1970-1971.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes items relating to both Professor Martin K Nurmi's teaching activities at Kent State University and to his non-teaching activities with the University's Faculty Senate. When the University was closed by a court injunction after the May 4, 1970 shootings on campus, Dr. Nurmi corresponded with his students several times during May and June, 1970, and he held some review sessions in his home to enable his students to complete their course work. The other major series in this collection relates to Nurmi's activities with the Faculty Senate. Of particular interest to researchers are the papers relating to the faculty observers program held in May, 1971; these include a phone log kept by one of the information centers established during the first remembrance of the shootings. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1970-1971.
resource.abstract: The collection includes items relating to both Professor Martin K Nurmi's teaching activities at Kent State University and to his non-teaching activities with the University's Faculty Senate. When the University was closed by a court injunction after the May 4, 1970 shootings on campus, Dr. Nurmi corresponded with his students several times during May and June, 1970, and he held some review sessions in his home to enable his students to complete their course work. The other major series in this collection relates to Nurmi's activities with the Faculty Senate. Of particular interest to researchers are the papers relating to the faculty observers program held in May, 1971; these include a phone log kept by one of the information centers established during the first remembrance of the shootings.

                  <abstract>Edward Dorn was born 2 April 1929 in Villa Grove, Illinois. He studied with Charles Olson at Black Mountain College and graduated in 1955. Mr. Dorn died in December 1999 at the age of 70.</abstract>

                  <abstract>This collection contains material relating to the teaching and research of Kent State University Political Science professor Richard W. Spencer, on Maurice Maschke, an early 20th century Cleveland politician, and the role of the political spoils system is also contained in these papers.</abstract>

nameEntries.original: Archives and Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Kent State University Honors College records include correspondences, course and catalog planning, and notes by the Dean of the Honors and Experimental College Donald "Mac" Hassler from 1976-1983. Also included are correspondence, minutes, and reports conducted by the Honors College Policy Council (HOCOPOCO) and the Committee on Innovative Change (the committee which established the Experimental Programs). Also included are various student and program publications including the literary magazines Ana, 1301 H, and Colloquy, Honors newsletters, "New Book" orientation books, event announcements, and brochures/pamphlets distributed by the Honors College. The notes included in the records range from course and catalog planning and HOCOPOCO meetings and projects to more minor notes on miscellaneous issues. </abstract>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Library. Southern
     Historical Collection.</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>McKissick, Floyd B. (Floyd Bixler), 1922-</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Floyd B. McKissick Papers, <unitdate>1940s-1980s</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <unitid>4930</unitid>
                  <langmaterial>Materials in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>157,000</extent>
                     <extent>126.0</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>Floyd B. McKissick (1922-1991) was born in
    Asheville, N.C. He was an attorney, businessman, and civil rights leader. McKissick married
    Evelyn Williams, with whom he had four children: Joycelyn; Andree; Floyd, Jr.; and Charmaine.</abstract>
                  <abstract>The collection contains materials documenting Floyd B. McKissick's
    work as an lawyer, businessman, and civil rights leader. Included are items pertaining to his
    law practice in Durham, N.C.; his service, beginning in 1966, as national director of the
    Congress of Racial Equality (CORE); his work as advisor to the National Association for the
    Advancement of Colored People (NAACP); and his interests in politics and education. Many items
    relate to Soul City, N.C., a town owned and operated by African Americans near Warrenton, N.C.
    Included are items describing the impact of Soul City on rural Warren County, N.C., and Vance
    County, N.C. Among the companies documented are McKissick Enterprises of New York and North
    Carolina; City Development, Inc.; HealthCo, Inc.; Madison and McKissick Development, Inc.;
    McKissick S.C. Associates; the Soul City Foundation and other Soul City companies; and the
    Warren Regional Planning Corporation. There are also a few items relating to the McKissick
    family and to his affiliation with the Republican Party at the local, state, and national
    levels.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Floyd B. McKissick Papers, 1940s-1980s
resource.abstract: Floyd B. McKissick (1922-1991) was born in    Asheville, N.C. He was an attorney, businessman, and civil rights leader. McKissick married    Evelyn Williams, with whom he had four children: Joycelyn; Andree; Floyd, Jr.; and Charmaine. The collection contains materials documenting Floyd B. McKissick's    work as an lawyer, businessman, and civil rights leader. Included are items pertaining to his    law practice in Durham, N.C.; his service, beginning in 1966, as national director of the    Congress of Racial Equality (CORE); his work as advisor to the National Association for the    Advancement of Colored People (NAACP); and his interests in politics and education. Many items    relate to Soul City, N.C., a town owned and operated by African Americans near Warrenton, N.C.    Included are items describing the impact of Soul City on rural Warren County, N.C., and Vance    County, N.C. Among the companies documented are McKissick Enterprises of New York and North    Carolina; City Development, Inc.; HealthCo, Inc.; Madison and McKissick Development, Inc.;    McKissick S.C. Associates; the Soul City Foundation and other Soul City companies; and the    Warren Regional Planning Corporation. There are also a few items relating to the McKissick    family and to his affiliation with the Republican Party at the local, state, and national    levels.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>George P. Garrett Papers, 
		  <unitdate>1929-2008</unitdate>
                     <unitdate>(bulk 1960-2000)</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Garrett, George P., 1929-2008</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>268 Linear Feet</extent>
                     <extent>177,929 Items</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Duke University. David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <physloc>For current information on
		  the location of these materials, please consult the
		  Library's online catalog.</physloc>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English.</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>George P. Garrett (1929-2008) was a poet, editor, author, and professor of English.</abstract>
                  <abstract>The papers of George P. Garrett span the years 1929 to 2000 with the bulk of the material being dated between 1960 and 1990. The papers were initially collected and assembled by author, bibliographer, and publisher Stuart T. Wright. Wright published a number of Garrett's works at his Palaemon Press and also assembled the Stuart Wright Bibliographic Collection of George Garrett (see related materials held by the Rubenstein Library). Additional materials were received by the Library directly from George Garrett. The papers document Garrett's literary career as an author of novels, short stories, poetry, and dramatic works (including filmscripts) and the tremendous influence he had as an English professor and an editor on an entire generation of writers, particularly in the South. Correspondence with numerous authors, publishers, and educators offers much information about the history of 20th-century Southern literature, publishing, and literary education. The collection is divided into the Writings Series (with subseries of Writings by Garrett, Writings Edited by Garrett, Writings by Others, and Proofs); the Correspondence Series (with 5 subseries of alphabetically and chronologically arranged correspondence); the Audiovisual Material Series; and the Miscellaneous Papers Series.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>

The collection is divided into the Writings Series (with subseries of Writings by Garrett, Writings Edited by Garrett, Writings by Others, and Proofs); the Correspondence Series (with 5 subseries of alphabetically and chronologically arranged correspondence); the Audiovisual Material Series; and the Miscellaneous Papers Series.

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection contains papers from former Kent State University Secretary George Urban regarding campus disturbances prior to and after the events of May 4, 1970. The collection contains material from 1969 through 1971. The collection includes papers highlighting the events leading up to and the aftermath of May 4, 1970. The contents of the collection consist of correspondence on the development of the Commission on KSU Violence, the visit of the Ohio Select Legislative Committee on Campus Unrest to Kent State University, questionnaires and surveys on May 4, and an analysis of the public's response to the Kent State Shootings prepared by the Department of Political Science. </abstract>

                     <role>

                  <abstract>Records of an ad hoc committee of students, alumni, and others at Kent State University (Ohio) organized to aid in the effort to establish an appropriate memorial to the four students killed during an anti-war demonstration on the campus on May 4, 1970.  The committee also endeavored to educate the public about that event and its aftermath, and about the history of the memorial controversy.  The collection documents the committee's fundraising and educational efforts, and includes chronologies of events, posters, clippings, correspondence, press releases, fundraising letters, advertisements, petitions, a speech by Glenn W.                      <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Bea McPherson papers, 1935-1993 (bulk 1940-1993).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection of papers relating to McPherson's organization of reunions of the Military Mapping Corps, a group of women recruited from colleges to work for the Army Map Service during World War II as well as materials documenting her career as a student at Kent State University from 1940 to 1943. This collection includes papers relating to Bea (Shaheen) McPherson as a Kent State University student (1940-1943) and as an active alumna. Included are a mathematics textbook McPherson used as a student and a scrapbook that she kept during this period. The scrapbook includes ephemera relating to college life and activities including sorority and fraternity parties, theatrical events, area restaurant menus, and newspaper clippings. Additional material in this collection relates to McPherson's service as a mapmaker for the Army Map Service during World World War II. McPherson organized reunions of the Military Mapmaking Corps members in 1968, 1976 and 1993. Reunion material includes correspondence, planning documents, publicity, photographs, and Defense Mapping Agency promotional materials. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kent State University</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: This collection documents the celebration of Kent State University's Semicentennial in 1959-1960. It includes some of the working documents of the Semicentennial Committee, photographs, press releases, periodical clippings, KSU publications and souvenirs produced for the Semicentennial.

resource.title: E. E. Cummings papers, 1870-1969
resource.abstract: Correspondence and working drafts of poems and other writings by American poet E. E. Cummings.

                     <persname>Johnson, J. T. (John Thomas), 1869-1956</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>J. T. Johnson papers</unittitle>
                  <physdesc>3 cubic feet (5 boxes = 2 record storage boxes, 2 document cases and 1 flat box)</physdesc>
                  <abstract>The J. T. Johnson papers, dating from the mid-19th to the mid-20th century, document both the personal and academic life of John Thomas Johnson, the first dean of Kent State Normal School and the head of the Agriculture Department. Johnson was an avid photographer and the collection includes photographs, as well as newspaper clippings and miscellaneous personal papers. Johnson's papers document the early history of Kent State University.</abstract>
                  <unitid>OhKeUSC0104</unitid>
                  <langmaterial>The records are in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <physloc>11th Floor</physloc>
                  <unitdate>1865-1950</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1880-1930</unitdate>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
